text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.11.3, Appeals Penalties, Return Preparer Penalty Cases.

Revised IRM 8.11.3 to incorporate Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0418-0006, Initial Conference Procedures for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases, dated April 23, 2018. This guidance consolidates initial case actions taken at different times to allow Appeals Technical Employees to validate case data when they start a substantive review of the case.

This IRM has been updated to add new IRM 8.11.3.1 Program Scope and Objectives and its related subsections to comply with the Deputy Commissioners of Services and Enforcement and Operations Support memo dated September 14, 2016, entitled Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls.
Appeals employees

Penalty Cases

) Purpose: This IRM section describes the process and procedures for Return Preparer Penalty cases in Appeals. Return Preparer Penalty cases originate from Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus and Area, Large Business and International (LB&I) and Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE) Divisions. These penalties are included within Chapter
, Subchapter B, Assessable Penalties, and are not return related penalties. are not subject to deﬁciency procedures. (
) Audience: Appeals Technical Employees (
) Policy Owner: Appeals Technical Guidance is under the Director, Examinations Programs and Referrals. (
) Program Owner: Appeals Technical Guidance is the program office for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization and is the Director of Technical Guidance. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this (
) This IRM adheres to Penalty Policy Statement, P-

which addresses fair and equitable implementation and application of penalty provisions and requires all Service functions to develop procedures that promote: • Consistency in the application of penalties compared to similar cases • Unbiased analysis of the facts in each case; and • The proper application of the law to the facts of the case. (

) Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensure Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRC
). See Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. For more information, see IRM
Appeals Operating Directives and Guidelines. (
) This IRM is supplemental guidance to IRM

, Penalty Handbook, Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties, and outlines the procedures working Return Preparer Penalty cases by Appeals Technical Employees. IRS has penalty and injunctive authority to address improper tax return ration and abusive transaction promoters. The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) contains penalties to stop fraudulent, unscrupulous, and/or incompetent tax return preparers, abusive transaction promoters, and material advisors who to furnish information or maintain lists with respect to reportable Penalty assertion is one enforcement vehicle for noncompliant return preparers, promoters, and material advisors. (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (C&OS) is the executive sible for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring tax administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the organization. (

) The Director, Policy, is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. Internal Revenue Manual

Purpose: This IRM section describes the process and procedures for working Return Preparer Penalty cases in Appeals. Return Preparer Penalty cases originate from Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus and Area, Large Business and International (LB&I) and Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE) Divisions. These penalties are included within Chapter
, Subchapter B, Assessable Penalties, and are not return related penalties. are not subject to deﬁciency procedures.

This IRM adheres to Penalty Policy Statement, P-20-1 which addresses fair and equitable implementation and application of penalty provisions and requires all Service functions to develop procedures that promote:

) This IRM is related to IRM

, which provides information regarding the servicewide preparer, promoter, and material advisor, penalties, policies, and Resources procedures. It serves as a supplemental procedural guide for Appeals Technical Employees. (
) This section addresses the procedures for return preparer penalties by Appeals. Return preparer penalties are imposed against the person or Preparer Penalty business that prepared a return. (
) The penalties discussed in this section are penalties proposed under: • IRC
, Understatement of Taxpayer’s Liability by a Tax Return Preparer, and • IRC
, Other Assessable Penalties with Respect to the of Tax Returns for Other Persons, and • IRC
, Disclosure or Use of Information by Preparers of Returns.
The penalties discussed in this section are penalties proposed under:
IRC
, Understatement of Taxpayer’s Liability by a Tax Return Preparer, and IRC
, Other Assessable Penalties with Respect to the Preparation of Tax Returns for Other Persons, and IRC
, Disclosure or Use of Information by Preparers of Returns.
) The deﬁnition of a tax return preparer for purposes of Sections
and
is provided in IRC
) and Treasury Regulation
) IRC
penalties can only apply if there is an understatement of tax liability. (
) The IRC
(a) penalty is the greater of $
or

% of the income derived (or to be derived) by the tax return preparer with respect to each return, amended return or claim for refund prepared if there is an understatement on the return or claim due to an unreasonable position taken on the return or claim that the preparer knew or reasonably should have known about. A position is unreasonable if:

position is unreasonable if: a. There was not substantial authority for the position and the position not disclosed. b. The position was disclosed but there was not reasonable basis for the position. c. The position is with respect to a tax shelter or reportable transaction under IRC
A and it is not reasonable to believe the position will more likely than not sustained on the merits. See Notice
, I.R.B.
Refer to IRM
, Tax Shelters and Reportable actions, for additional guidance on the application of IRC
) The IRC
(b) penalty is the greater of $
or
% of the income (or to be derived) by the tax return preparer with respect to returns, returns, and claims for refund prepared for taxable years ending after December

The penalty may be imposed against a tax return preparer if: a. There is an understatement of liability, on a return or claim for refund prepared by the preparer, which is due to a willful attempt in any to understate the tax liability by the preparer, or b. The preparer has recklessly or intentionally disregarded rules or tions. (
) Reduce the IRC
(b) penalty by the amount of the IRC
(a) penalty both the IRC
(a) and (b) penalties are asserted against the preparer on the same return or claim. (
) Because the IRC
(b) penalty involves willfulness, there is no statutory period for assessment of this penalty. On tax return preparer penalties asserted under section
(a) and
, the three year statute of for assessment begins to run on the ﬁling date of the return or claim for The statute of limitations on assessment for the section
(a) and
penalties may be extended using a Form
-D, Consent to Extend the on Assessment of Tax Return Preparer Penalty. IRC
(d) addresses periods of limitation. (
) Refer to IRM
, IRC
Understatement of Taxpayer’s Liability by Return Preparer, for additional information. (
) These penalties are generally processed under the pre-assessment penalty procedures.

) The penalty under IRC

is assessed against preparers who: a. receive compensation for preparing a tax return, or engage in the business of preparing or providing services in connection with the ration of tax returns; and b. disclose any information furnished to him or her in connection with the preparation of any return; or c. use any information furnished to him or her for any purpose other prepare or assist in preparing the taxpayer’s return. See IRM 20.1.6.4, IRC 6694 Understatement of Taxpayer’s Liability by Tax Return Preparer, for detailed procedures.
Preparer Penalty Cases 8.11.3

Some penalties are related to positions taken or items reported on underlying tax returns (the related tax return). In general, if there is an unagreed related income tax case, the unagreed preparer penalty case will not be sent to Appeals before the related tax case is submitted to Appeals. Examination will include in the preparer case ﬁle information on the current status and location of the related return.

In general, if there is an unagreed related income tax case, the unagreed preparer penalty case will not be sent to Appeals before the related tax case is submitted to Appeals. Examination will include in the preparer case ﬁle information on the current status and location of the related return.

) Return preparer penalty issues were re-designated as Appeals Coordinated Issues, Category of Case (ACIcc) on August
Review and concur- rence is no longer required before ﬁnalizing any resolution for a return penalty. (
) Appeals employees having a work unit with a return preparer penalty issue must make a referral to Domestic Operations through their manager upon as- signment or preliminary review using Form
, Appeals Technical Referral.
(09-24-2013) Return Preparer Penalties as Appeals Coordinated Issues (ACI)

Appeals employees having a work unit with a return preparer penalty issue must make a referral to Domestic Operations through their manager upon as- signment or preliminary review using Form 13381, Appeals Technical Guidance
Note: Return preparer penalties under IRC 6713 are not coordinated and a referral should not be made.
Refer to the “Domestic Ops” tab on the Appeals Website gov/lbsp/default.htm for list of Technical Specialists.

8.11 Penalties Worked in Appeals

a. Form 5402, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, will be included in the closing package. It should include information on the revised penalty amounts needed to update ACDS. b. Form 8278 will be included and will require processing. (3) The following closing codes apply: Determination Made CLOSINGCD Sustained (penalties are not removed) 14 Abated (penalties are fully removed) 15 Partially Abated (only part of penalties are 16 removed) Premature Referral (case returned to Examination) 20 (4) APS will assess or abate penalty per the ATE prepared Forms 5402 and 8278 instructions. a. Penalties are assessed using TC 240 and the applicable reference code. (5) If closing a case as a premature referral that contains an IRC 6695(g) penalty, the ATE will advise APS to return the case to the appropriate EITC coordinator by notating this in the other remarks section of the Form 5402. The list of EITC coordinators can be found at http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/exam/tip/rp/contacts/ 12536.aspx.
